entry.title: Example of how to do the maintenance of IBAN for the Business Partner - SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud
entry.content:
***Image/data in this Blog is from SAP internal systems, sample data, or demo systems. Any resemblance to real data is purely coincidental.***

Hello SAP S/4HANA Cloud Community,

Introduction:
I work with the LO-MD-BP-2CL component in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition, focusing on Business Partner functionality. Iâ€™d like to share some insights with the community regarding maintenance of the International Bank Account Number (IBAN), as Iâ€™ve come across several incidents involving incorrect validations for various countries.

In this blog, I will show a simple example from specific country and outline the steps to correctly implement maintenance of the International Bank Account Number (IBAN).

Steps:

  1. Open Basic Settings Application Platform and Infrastructure: General Settings -> SSCUI 102592 Set Country-Specific Checks and select configure button as shown in image.

2. Select Country France for purpose of the example

 

3. Check out the SAP recommended settings for countries in which the International Bank Account Number (IBAN) is used by checking out the Knowledge Based Article  1012293 - IBAN and maintenance of bank master data.

**Screenshot from KBA 1012293 for France Country**

4. Please fill out above details in fields Key for bank directory, Bank account number and Bank number length - Length and Checking rule.


Best regards,
Viplav Gadewar
SAP Support | SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition | Business Partner

entry.title: Re: OSS-Bericht (One Stop Shop) fÃ¼r Umsatzsteuer â€“ SAP Pu...
entry.content:
Hi @Stanco ,

 

The key issue is that SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud historically did not have a dedicated, standard, out-of-the-box solution for comprehensive OSS reporting. Take some alternative approach.

I guess below are the feilds required for EU OSS return.

-Destination Country: The EU Member State where the goods/services are consumed.
-Net Amount: The value of the supply excluding VAT.
-Tax Amount: The VAT amount charged.
-VAT Rate: The specific VAT rate applied in the destination country.
-Tax Code: The SAP tax code used for the transaction.
-Type of Supply: (e.g., goods, services, specific digital services).
-Customer VAT ID (if applicable): For B2B transactions, though OSS primarily focuses on B2C.
Date of Supply: The date when the transaction occurred.

Use standard CDS veiw and create few custom CDS views.

Standard CDS view
-I_JournalEntryItem: This is a fundamental CDS view for financial accounting line items, including tax data. It contains fields like CompanyCode, FiscalYear, AccountingDocument, GLAccount, TaxCode, TransactionCurrencyAmount, AmountInCompanyCodeCurrency, VATRegistrationCountry (which might be the destination country if configured correctly for cross-border sales), Customer, etc.
-I_TaxCode, I_TaxCodeText, I_TaxType: These can help you retrieve details about your tax codes, their descriptions, and tax types.

Create a Custom CDS View (using "Custom CDS Views" App):
-Primary Data Source: Start with a core view like I_JournalEntryItem.
-Add Associations/Joins: Join with other relevant CDS views to pull in all necessary data points. For example:
-Join with I_Customer or I_BusinessPartner to get customer address details, which can help determine the destination country if not directly available from the transaction.
-Join with I_BillingDocumentItem or I_SalesOrderItem if you need data specifically from sales or billing documents that might not be fully captured in the financial journal entry.
-Select Fields: Choose all the fields required for your OSS return (tax code, net amount, tax amount, destination country, VAT rate, etc.). Then define filters and create analytical query.

By combining careful planning of data requirements with the powerful extensibility options of Custom CDS Views, you should be able to extract the necessary data for your EU OSS VAT return

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos. This motivates me to serve you better.
Appreciate your feedback.
Thanks,
Divyesh

entry.title: Re: Extended situation handling issues on SAP S/4HANA 202...
entry.content:
Hi Mben, 

let me try to answer some of your questions: 

  1. In the case of Event-based triggers, which event should I choose? Why does it say "No instance detected"?
    Did you check the logs? For the Situation Extended Framework the log object is SIT2.
    I wrote a blog on logs for the Standard Framework - the logs for the Extended Framework are kind of similar. 
    https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/log-analysis-for-the-standard-framework-of-situation-handling/ba-p/13532195 
    If you have subscribed the events in the Situation Type you are using, this should work. However the events also need to be trigged from their source. You'll need to contact the "owners" of the events to understand when they get triggered. To find that I'd recommend using https://api.sap.com/ and select the respective Product, such as S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition. 
    We (the Situation Framework) are only processing the events, but we don't have any deeper knowledge on them.

  2. Why is the notification shown only in the Inbox icon, but not in the "My Situations" section on the Home screen?
    Not sure if I understand this 100%. Are you talking about the "My Situations - Extended" app or the "ToDos" directly on the Fiori Launchpad? Both should be visible, maybe the backend services are not active in your system. Please check the network console of your browser.
    As the services are usually active in the S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition I assume you're using S/4HANA Private Cloud Edition.
    The documentation for the services is here
    https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_ON-PREMISE/8308e6d301d54584a33cd04a9861bc52/40db8e05782b460e9490381b29ab7aa3.html?version=2023.002&locale=en-US 
    You'll need 

    • C_SITN2MYSITUATION_V4 for My Situations - Extended and 

    • C_SITNINSTANCETP_CDS for the "ToDos"

  3. With batch-based triggers, how can I schedule the job to run every 5 minutes instead of every 3 hours?
    That is not allowed/possible - the reasons is protecting the system from performance issues as batch runs always evaluate the complete trigger object (view) - certainly only those selected via the condition filters. Anyways there might be a lot and that might impact the overall system performance. I belief you're already dong the right thing; use events as here only a single object is checked.

I hope I could answer at least some of your questions. 

-  Axel

entry.title: Re: Mass Printing of Purchase order: Public cloud
entry.content:
Use the Output Parameter Determination app to define how and when POs should be printed. Go to the app: Output Parameter Determination, Select Purchase Order as the document type and Configure the following determination steps:

  • Output Type: Choose PURCHASE_ORDER
  • Dispatch Time: Set to Scheduled (3) for background printing
  • Channel: Choose Print
  • Receiver: Define the recipient (e.g., supplier or internal)
  • Printer Settings: Assign the correct print queue

Use the Maintain Print Queues app to define where the output should go. Create a custom print queue (donâ€™t use the default one). Assign a communication user (from communication scenario SAP_COM_0466) and link the queue to SAP Cloud Print Manager for physical printing or PDF generation.

Install and Configure SAP Cloud Print Manager which pulls documents from the print queue and sends them to your local printer or saves them as PDFs. Download from the Install Additional Software app. Install with admin rights. Connect it to your print queue and local printer.

Use the Print Scheduled Purchase Orders app to trigger printing. Select multiple POs. Ensure they meet the output determination criteria. The system will route them to the print queue for processing.

If you need PDFs in bulk, consider using the Display Document Output Requests (F2517) app to download PDFs one by one. Building a custom Fiori app via Developer Extensibility to Select multiple POs, Trigger output generation & Fetch and bundle PDFs for download

For SAP PaPM Cloud Default Plan Standard and Universal Model, if you allow your connection to be transported to another tenant(could be your SAP PaPM Cloud BYOD plan), then the configuration of your Connections will be also carried over from the Export and Import activity.

entry.title: Re: Period Control Depreciation and Risk of IFRS Compliance
entry.content:
Hello,

What SAP does:

-SAP S/4HANA enables IFRS compliance through:
-Configurable depreciation keys, accounting principles, and ledger frameworks
-Modules like RE-FX and CLM-FX designed to meet IFRS 16 requirements
-ACDOCA-based universal journal for transparency and traceability

What SAP does not do:

-It does not prevent users from configuring non-compliant methods
-It does not validate whether your selected depreciation logic, lease handling, or reporting structures violate IFRS
-It allows backend logic combinations (like Cartesian joins in CDS views or journal logic) that could result in distorted or misclassified data if not carefully validated

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos. This motivates me to serve you better.
Appreciate your feedback.
Thanks,
Divyesh

entry.title: Re: Deactivated leased asset
entry.content:
Hi @Aninoo ,

Check couple of things.

1. Check Report Selection Criteria
When you run the transaction, check if there are filters for status, lease end date, or deactivation indicators.
Use a date filter (e.g., term end date) to limit the scope to currently active leases only.

2. Use Asset Status Filters
Add a filter for "deactivation indicator" or status = "Active" only.
In FI-AA, check if the asset is fully retired or has been marked as inactive.

3. Update Asset Master Data (AS02)
Ensure the lease term end date is correctly maintained.
Ensure the asset has been marked as retired or deactivated in master data if applicable.

4. Customize or Use a Different Report
If you're using a standard TC like S_ALR_87011990 (Asset History Sheet), consider customizing the report via Report Painter or SQVI/SQ01 to include your own logic for filtering based on lease end date.
In RE-FX, use reports like REISLE or RECN for better lease-specific filters.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos. This motivates me to serve you better.
Appreciate your feedback.
Thanks,
Divyesh

entry.title: The E in Event-Driven Architecture: Introducing SAPâ€™s new Event-Add for ERP
entry.content:
Introducing SAPâ€™s new Event-Add for ERP

The smallest building blocks of an Event-Driven Architecture are events. You could even argue that they are the most important building block of an EDA as well. Without suitable events â€“ no surprise â€“ no event-driven architecture.

Now it has gotten a lot easier and straightforward to create suitable events for your event-driven use case: SAP has just released the Event Add-On for ERP. This add-on is geared at exposing and consuming events to and from SAP Integration Suite, advanced event mesh, therefore works with SAP's flagship event broker.

Back in Time: The Early Days of Business EDA

 I still remember the days when I had started working on EDA, years and years ago. Often, we had identified event-driven use cases with customers and had then not been able to start executing on these because the required event had not been available in SAP S/4HANA. In those days, SAP S/4HANA had only offered a two-digit number of standard events. Quite often, the event you wanted and needed was not there in SAP S/4HANA. Or it did not contain the right payload. And back then, the events were not extensible. You had no chance to create custom events. Often customers were not able to start their projects due to a lack of suitable events.

Luckily, event-driven architectures still kicked off with the events that were available. And both customers and SAP were quite innovative in respect to how to use and how to show the power of event-driven architectures.

The picture above shows a scene from TechEd 2016 Las Vegas, where former SAP CTO Bjoern Goerke managed to charge the flux compensator of his DeLorean with the required 1.21 gigawatts, based on events generated by the audience by shaking their smartphones.

The E in EDA today

Nowadays, things have changed some. There are plenty of standard events in SAP S/4HANA and you can build your own custom events based on RAP. Quite a number of standard events are already extensible - based on S/4HANAâ€™s derived events concept. Plus, there are a lot of new features that allow backend-based filtering of events, and soon it is planned to provide AEMâ€™s end-to-end distributed tracing to already start from SAP S/4HANA. So, yes, weâ€™ve made major steps forward and we still make progress every month.

What is important to note is that a lot of the improvements come with newer SAP backends only. S/4HANA versions 2022 and newer or SAP S/4HANA, public cloud edition come with a lot of EDA features. They primarily build on the RAP approach to create events.

Now, if you have an older backend (older S/4HANA or SAP ECC) or are not a big fan of RAP, we had introduced a second approach to expose events: SAP Application Interface Framework (AIF). It works with SAP S/4HANA and/or SAP ECC in combination with SAP Integration Suite, advanced event mesh. Exposing events via AIF is a good option if you are already using SAP AIF extensively, have the required skillset, and are not shy to code.

Now, what about customers that do not want to code? What about customers who require a large number of custom events? What about customers that have mixed landscapes with both SAP S/4HANA and SAP ECC?

Enlarging the E in EDA

You might have already noticed it when looking at the diagram above - as of lately, there is a third option to event-enable SAP on-premise backends: the SAP Integration Suite, advanced event mesh, event add-on for ERP (in short Event Add-On for ERP).

SAP has decided to introduce the Event Add-On for ERP to further improve event exposure options for our event-driven ecosystem. Consider the Event-Add-On for ERP as a premium and convenience option that comes with a low-code/no-code approach to create sophisticated, clean-core compliant custom events in just a few minutes.

The Event Add-On complements SAPâ€™s other options and, very important, SAPâ€™s goal is to make the different options work well together in future to allow to use them in combination as easily as possible. 

A First Look at the Event Add-On for ERP

Let me try to describe what the Event-Add On is in a few sentences:

  • The Event Add-On enables real-time, event-driven, bi-directional communication and batch loads from both SAP S/4HANA and SAP ERP Central Component (SAP ECC) to SAP Integration Suite, advanced event mesh.
  • The Add-On is already available via SAP through various commercial models (BTPEA, CPEA, PAYG, Subscription via SAP Store).
  • It supports different deployment options of SAP S/4HANA and SAP ECC (including on-premises and SAP S/4HANA, private cloud edition)
  • It allows to create custom events in a code-less or alternatively pro-code way and offers extensible payloads
  • CDS views, classic tables, IDocs can be used for event payload creation
  • Comes with templates for selected custom events
  • Major parts of the technology have already been in successful use for several years and is now available in an SAP offering specifically tailored for SAP Integration Suite, advanced event mesh
  • Scales to enterprise grade numbers of events exposed

Now letâ€™s have a closer look at event triggers. The Add-On offers a number of standard triggers and many custom trigger options. 

Standard triggers

  • SAP Business Object events
  • SAP Business Transaction Events (BTE)
  • RAP BOs
  • SAP Change Documents (CDHDR/CDPOS)
  • IDocs
  • SAP Output Determination
  • Replications from SAP CAR, EWM, SLT

Selected custom trigger options

  • Custom business object events
  • Calling Event Add-On framework via ABAP-code
  • Scheduling an Event Add-On job

Important: the Event Add-On for ERP is both resilient and highly reliable. It provides a monitoring application, offers failover & reprocessing, and allows for alerting.

New Blog Series: A Second, Third, and Fourth Look at the Add-On

To provide you with a chance to dive deeper into using the Event Add-On for ERP we would like to use this blog start off a blog series on the Event Add-on.

Expect more blogs on the add-on in the coming weeks, starting with an overview blog and then with blogs going deeper and deeper into selected topics.

We will link the available blogs here once they are available. Please stay tuned!

Links

In case that you donâ€™t want to wait any longer, here are some links that provide you with additional information on the Event Add-On for ERP:

Discovery Center Mission on Event Add-On for ERP and Advanced Event Mesh

ASAPIO Partner Page on the Event Add-On for ERP

SAP Discovery Center for AEM and Event Add-On

SAP Help: Connecting the Add-On to AEM

SAP Store for AEM

entry.title: Administration of SAP PaPM Cloud using BYOD SAP Datasphere (in SAP BDC)
entry.content:
NOTE: This blogpost is applicable both for SAP Datasphere, SAP Datasphere in SAP Business Data Cloud (SAP BDC) and SAP Data Warehouse Cloud (SAP DWC).

Hello Everyone,

Welcome to the 2nd part of the blog post for the discussion on how you can Administer your SAP Profitability and Performance Management Cloud(SAP PAPM Cloud) with Bring Your Own Database(BYOD) plan.

On the previous blog post Administration of SAP PAPM Cloud using BYOD Standalone SAP HANA Cloud, we have discussed on how you can administer your SAP PAPM Cloud BYOD plan using Standalone Hana Cloud Database(Standalone HCDB).

Now, I will show you how to Administer your SAP PAPM Cloud BYOD Plan using SAP Datasphere as your database.

It is important for you to know that SAP Datasphere uses a runtime database. If you will have a BYOD plan with SAP PAPM Cloud and SAP Datasphere as your database, your SAP PAPM Cloud will also use the same runtime database from SAP Datasphere.

Runtime databases are usually restricted only for administrators. Even so, with the proper authorization or sharing of entities from SAP Datasphere, we can still share data between Spaces.

To maintain the data governance in SAP Datasphere, administrators are creating Spaces where members can acquire, prepare and model data.

These spaces can be used like a working environment for each department within the company.

Letâ€™s say, you just recently subscribed to SAP PAPM Cloud BYOD plan using your SAP Datasphere as its database, then it is recommended to have your own space that will be capable of accessing calculated and processed data from the artifacts of SAP PAPM Cloud.

This setup will also provide a restriction only for the SAP Datasphere database user added within the space and maintain the governance of artifacts as users can control what can be shared to other spaces.

Since you can use an existing SAP Datasphere to be the database of your BYOD plan of SAP PAPM Cloud, it is normal to expect existing multiple spaces. For example, the image below.

To give an example on this blog post, I explicitly created these two(2) spaces which are HRDEPT space where we will get the data from, while PAPMCLOUD space is where I performed the Universal Model HDI Container mapping.

Our goal on this blog post is to perform data consumption from HRDEPT space to SAP PAPM Cloud modeling which can perform complex calculation and data processing.

Initially, tables and views are not accessible from different spaces. These entities need are to be shared manually by the Space Administrator before other space can read. To give an example see image below:

For more information about objects sharing, see Sharing Entities and Task Chains to Other Spaces.

Once the table is shared, PAPMCLOUD space can now create a view on top of the entity shared by the HRDEPT.

Do not forget to enable the toggle Expose For Consumption to make the view available in the SAP HANA Database Explorer later when we perform the granting of privileges.

For more information on how to create views, see Importing Tables and Views from Sources.

In the SAP HANA Database Explorer, as expected, the View created above will be visible when we logged in as an SAP Datasphere database user.

Disclaimer: All data records being shown above are all test data and for demo purposes only.

SAP Datasphere database users under our Space PAPMCLOUD can access our views and perform granting  SELECT privilege to other users.

Probably you got some hints when we say SAP Datasphere database users can provide an authorization to other users.

Letâ€™s now proceed with the introduction of BYOD plan of SAP PAPM Cloud.

Similar to Standalone HANA Cloud, this blog post will be divided into three(3) important chapters so you can focus on what is relevant for your use case.

  1. Introducing technical users in SAP Datasphere.
  2. Authorization Grants for Standard Model
  3. Authorization Grants for Universal Model

Introducing technical users in SAP Datasphere

Since you can use multiple SAP PAPM Cloud tenants on one SAP Datasphere it is necessary for you to know what are the available schemas you can use to perform such integration in your own database.

SAP_PAPM_ADMIN like user

Once you subscribed to  SAP PAPM Cloud that uses BYOD plan, a user will be generated in Administration > Settings that you can use to login on your Standalone HCDB.

SAP_PAPM_SM_HDI_<TENANTID>_<UNIQUEID>_RT.

Please take note of this IDs as it will be the indicator who owns the artifact on the Database level in case you have multiple tenants connected to your Standalone HCDB.

Please take note that the Database user above does not equate to the roles granted to SAP_PAPM_ADMIN from default subscription. In BYOD, you have the freedom to grant the roles which you think are needed for your user.

If you wish to add roles like those granted for SAP_PAPM_ADMIN default plan by default, you may visit this Database Role PAPM_OPERATOR_ROLE to check the roles.

Below is a sample step on how you can perform the granting of roles:

  1. Create PAPM_OPERATOR_ROLE example:
CREATE ROLE PAPM_OPERATOR_ROLE;â€‹

      b. Using the information in Database Role PAPM_OPERATOR_ROLE, perform the following SQL, example:

GRANT CATALOG READ TO PAPM_OPERATOR_ROLE;â€‹

To verify you may check in the Database the Role Management section in Database.

Do this for all the succeeding grants.

C. Once done, assign this role to the SAP_PAPM_ADMIN like user which can be found in database settings, example:

GRANT PAPM_OPERATOR_ROLE TO SAP_PAPM_SM_HDI_<TENANTID>_<UNIQUEID>;

Technical schemas on Standalone HCDB BYOD plan

For you to have an idea with how you can understand the naming convention of schema available after BYOD subscription, refer to the screenshot and table below.

 

Model

Default Subscription

BYOD Subscription

Standard Model

SAP_PAPM

SAP_PAPM_SM_<TENANTID> is the schema where all artifacts from Standard Model can be found

Standard Model

SAP_PAPM_ADMIN

SAP_PAPM_SM_HDI_<TENANTID>_<UNIQUEID>_RT is the database username in Database Settings 

Universal Model

SAP_PAPM_UM

SAP_PAPM_UM_<TENANTID> is the schema where all artifacts from Universal Model can be found

Standard Model

Following the procedures added in the help portal Connections, you may start performing Inbound and Outbound scenarios for Standard Model given by the steps below.

Inbound Scenarios

Accessing artifacts of Space schema from SAP Datasphere

Your Space schema can be used as an Authoring schema on one of the connections in SAP PAPM Cloud to be used for consumption.

Initially, if you are going to create a Connection in Connection Management screen, your schema is not yet visible to be used as expected.

This is because we need to grant a privilege to the technical schema of SAP PAPM Cloud Standard Model which is the equivalent of SAP_PAPM schema.

  1. Login on your SAP HANA Database explorer using your Database user from SAP Datasphere > Space Management > Database Access with the SQL Statement below:
CONNECT <DSP#DBUSER> PASSWORD <â€Passwordâ€>;â€‹

      2. Once logged in as the SAP Datasphere Database user, perform the SQL Statement syntax below:

GRANT SELECT ON "<SPACESCHEMA>"."OBJECT_NAME" TO "SAP_PAPM_SM_<XXXXX>"â€‹


To maintain the governance in SAP Datasphere. Database user are only capable of granting privilege on specific object under the space schema.

     3. After granting of privileges, you can now go back to your Connection Management Screen and your external schema will be available then you can choose the artifact you prefer. For example, see image below:


The created connection will be eligible for usage in Modeling and from here, we can now successfully consume the table from your existing external schema.

Outbound Scenarios

Expose Y table entries to SAP Datasphere Database user

In order to read SAP PAPM SM Y-tables, you can utilize the SAP HANA Connection in SAP Datasphere by using the credentials provided in the Administration > Settings in SAP PAPM SM Standard Model.

Related information

Integrating SAP PaPM Cloud & SAP Datasphere (in SAP BDC)

Universal Model

Following the procedures added in the help portal Manage Connections, you may start performing Inbound and Outbound scenarios for Universal Model given by the steps below.

Inbound Scenarios

Accessing artifacts of Space schema from SAP Datasphere

Your existing  SAP Datasphere space schema can be used as the Target HANA Schema on your connection in your Universal Model.

Still using the Datasphere database user used from Standard Model scenarios, initially, if you are going to create a Connection in Manage Connection screen, your schema is not yet visible to be used as expected.

This is because we need to grant a privilege to the technical schema of SAP PAPM Cloud Universal Model.

  1. Login on your SAP HANA Database explorer using your Database user from SAP Datasphere > Space Management > Database Access with the SQL Statement below:
CONNECT <DSP#DBUSER> PASSWORD <â€Passwordâ€>;â€‹

      2. Once logged in as the SAP Datasphere Database user, perform the SQL Statement syntax below:

GRANT SELECT ON "< SPACESCHEMA >"."<OBJECT_NAME>" TO "SAP_PAPM_UM_<XXXXX>::external_privileges_role" WITH GRANT OPTION;â€‹

This SQL statement above is for enabling your Space schema to the list of schema on the creation of HANA Schema connection.

However, on the saving of creation of connection, you will encounter and error like the image below:

With this, you will be needing to perform another grant of privilege to the technical schema of Universal Model which you can refer to the syntax below:

GRANT SELECT ON "<SPACESCHEMA>"."<OBJECT_NAME>" TO "SAP_PAPM_UM_<XXXXX>#OO" WITH GRANT OPTION;

Once the granting of privileges is done, you may now perform the mapping on your available Model from Target HANA Schema, Activate the Environment and then go to Show data screen to validate the table.

Outbound Scenarios

Expose Z table entries to SAP Datasphere

SAP PAPM UM artifacts are stored into the HDI Container mapped on SAP Datasphere upon subscription. Therefore, users may use it directly as source when configuring Graphical views in the Data Builder.

For more information, see Importing Tables and Views from Sources.

That will be it! I am hoping that scenarios above are helpful in case you will be using the SAP PAPM Cloud BYOD plan using SAP Datasphere as its database.

You may also refer to our official documentation on:

  • Standard Model Administration of BYOD Plan on SAP Datasphere Database Administration
  • Universal Model Administration of BYOD Plan on SAP Datasphere Database Administration

entry.title: Re: Situation Handling: Advanced Configuration of Situation Types (5-5)
entry.content:
Hi JÃ¼rgen,

unfortunately there is no easy way to achieve this. When Situation Handling receives the event about changes in a business object, there is no user context, so we are unable to tell or store who was responsible for the change. The only option you have to notify a user about changes in the state of a situation is to have them in the list of responsible users (either via team or via rule). The extended framework provides more options to configure when people will be notified and with what text, but the general constraint remains.

Best regards,
Sebastian

entry.title: New: Value Analytics for SAP Fieldglass
entry.content:
Upon the release of the Q2 2025 SAP Analytics Cloud Content and SAP Datasphere Content package, a new page has been added to the SAP Value Analytics for Procurement story that is entirely dedicated towards SAP Fieldglass KPIs. This is the first of many updates to the tool that will expand its functionality far beyond SAP Ariba Procurement, allowing companies to analyze spend at a wider visibility than ever before.

The new page in SAP Value Analytics for Procurement provides a big picture summary of SAP Fieldglass spend categories. Just like the other stories, users are presented with a clean and simplified view of data from select KPIs. Companies that choose to operationalize this new page may easily gain insights on their SAP Fieldglass data, including:

  • The influence of workforce management efficiency on overall revenue
  • Costs incurred by ensuring projects & hiring processes stay compliant
  • The financial impact of maintaining a quality workforce

If providing users with a way to further operationalize SAP Fieldglass data in a comprehensive analysis of spend piques your interest, please continue reading for more information on how to activate the new SAP Fieldglass page in SAP Value Analytics for Procurement.

1. SAP Analytics Cloud - Strategic Spend Overview

After opening the SAP Value Analytics for Procurement story in SAP Analytics Cloud, navigate to the page entitled â€œFieldglassâ€. Along with the title, the top module contains a summary of spend related to high-value KPIs in SAP Fieldglass. A dimension module with a "Date Range" filtering option appears below the title module, followed by three data visualization modules, entitled â€œCost Savingsâ€, â€œComplianceâ€, and â€œProcess Improvementâ€ to represent the major categories of Fieldglass Transactions.

SAP Fieldglass page view in SAP Analytics Cloud

2. SAP Datasphere Integration for SAP Value Analytics for Procurement

Initiating the activation of the SAP Fieldglass page requires some manual configuration. After the necessary reports are built in Fieldglass, the user must download them in CSV format and upload them into SAP Datasphere. All other relevant objects can be found in the SAP_CONTENT space.

As of Q2 2025, the images below are the most updated views of the integration architecture and the SAP Datasphere objects included in the SAP Value Analytics for Procurement package.

Integration architecture (updated to include SAP Fieldglass assets)

SAP Datasphere objects view (updated to Include SAP Fieldglass objects)

As a reminder, the following naming conventions have been used:
SM -> Supplier Management
SC -> Sourcing & Contracts
BI -> Buying & Invoicing
FG -> Fieldglass

The data modeling for the SAP Fieldglass page follows the layered approach of content development in SAP Datasphere. Here, the set up for SAP Fieldglass Project analysis is used as the example, the photo below describing the direction of the model layers:

SAP Fieldglass data model workflow

The Integration Layer (IL) contains the local table SAP Fieldglass: Project (LT) (SAP_Fieldglass_SRC_Project_MA), which was created in a manual file upload, as mentioned previously. In addition, this layer also includes the abstracting view, SAP Fieldglass: Project (IL) (SAP_PROC_FG_IL_Project), which adds data specific to the realm.

The Harmonization Layer (HL), SAP Fieldglass: Project (HL) (SAP_PROC_FG_HL_ProjectSQL), acts as the Fact View that combines Fieldglass project data with the Date Grid view.

Finally, the Reporting Layer (RL) uses the Analytic Model SAP Fieldglass: Project (RL) (SAP_PROC_FG_RL_Project) to define additional calculated measures and expose the data to the SAP Fieldglass page in SAP Analytics Cloud.

3. Content Documentation

Thank you for reading this SAP Community article!

To view the blog post on the original release of SAP Value Analytics for SAP Ariba Procurement in Q2 2024, please view â€˜Maximize Value with Value Analytics for SAP Aribaâ€™ by @SimonKranig.

For further instructions on configuring SAP Value Analytics for Procurement, please view this discovery mission.

More details on the SAP Fieldglass content package for SAP Value Analytics for Procurement can be found on this SAP Help page.

Have questions and want to share with other users? Feel free to post a question in the community:
SAP Community > SAP Analytics Cloud
SAP Community > SAP Datasphere

Procedure

entry.title: Re: Highlighting a field conditionally
entry.content:
Without content, the field has no width, and hence can't be highlighted.

Consider creating a formula that returns DATE_SHIPPED as a STRING if DATE_SHIPPED has a value or a STRING of several spaces otherwise.  Use that formula on the report layout and apply the color highlight logic to it.

entry.title: HANA Client for Node.js and explicit connection pooling
entry.content:
Hello,

I ran some experiments with the explicit connection pool API of the HANA client for Node.js:

createPool({String | Object}[, Object]) Method | SAP Help Portal

When I create a connection pool with these pool options:

{
  maxConnectedOrPooled: 10,
  poolCapacity: 1, 
  maxPooledIdleTime: 60,
  pingCheck: true,
}

and watch the network connections of the node process e. g. with `lsof -i -a -p <pid>` I can see that the pool keeps one connection open with the database at all times, which is what I expect.

But if the connection is idle for longer then 60s, it is still kept open. Only once I do another request and a connection is to be taken from the pool, it evicts the old connection and creates a new one.
 
For me this defies the purpose of the connection pool to always have a usable connection available. It also makes no sense from a resource point of view to keep a connection open which is never to be reused!
 
I expect that many developers will take the code from the documentation page
var pool = hana.createPool("ServerNode=myhost-hanacloud.ondemand.com:443;uid=myusername;pwd=mypassword",
"poolCapacity=25;maxConnectedOrPooled=50;maxPooledIdleTime=60;pingCheck=true");

Not only does it specify a pool capacity of 25 idle, 50 total which is too high for most applications. It also leads to having up to 25 connections open with the database which, after 60s, will be completely useless since they all will be evicted the next time a connection is to be retrieved from the pool. I tested this.

So, is the HANA Client broken for maxPooledIdleTime?

entry.title: Primary flag handling for email and phone information
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

During the recruiting process, we first collect private contact information, which has to be set as the primary contact in the system. Later, once the business contact information are created (such as the business email and phone), we want to make those the new primary contact.

However, updating the primary contact via API or import is not possible unless we also modify the original (private) contact record. It would be much more effective to derive it dynamically or allow a conditional logicâ€”for example: if only one phone type exists, set it as primary, or: if two phone types exist, use "business" as primary.

Weâ€™re genuinely surprised this isnâ€™t a more widely reported issue. It causes significant challenges when integrating contact data across Recruiting, SuccessFactors, and external systems like Identity Management. In our case, business contact details come from HCM, but since the private contact information from Recruiting must be set as primary (because no other types exist yet), we cannot update the business info without also updating the existing informationâ€”because only one record can be marked as primary at a time.

If you are facing similar problems, weâ€™ve submitted an improvement request to make the field handling more flexible.

Weâ€™d really appreciate it if you could check it out and leave a vote if it affects you too.
Thanks a lot!

Julia

entry.title: Streamline SAC Custom Widget Development with Local Server
entry.content:
Developing custom widgets for SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) enables developers to extend the platformâ€™s built-in visualizations. But the development workflow can be repetitive. The cycle of editing code, bundling files, and uploading them to SAC for every small change slows down development.

This blog post introduces a streamlined workflow using a local Express.js server to serve your custom widget files directly from your development machine. This eliminates the need for repeated uploads and allows changes to be reflected immediately in SAC with a simple browser refresh.

Use the Sample Widget Repository to Get Started Quickly

To help you get started, a ready-to-use GitHub repository is available. It contains:

  • A complete sample custom widget project

  • A package.json file for managing npm dependencies

  • A server.js file to launch a local Express.js server

  • A manifest file (podiumWidget.json) to upload to SAP Analytics Cloud

Steps to Run the Sample

Clone the Repository

git clone https://github.com/lkannan/analytics-cloud-creating-custom-widgets-learning-journey.git
cd analytics-cloud-creating-custom-widgets-learning-journey

Install Dependencies

npm install

Start the Local Server

npm start

This will launch the development server at: http://localhost:3000

Load the Widget in SAP Analytics Cloud

  • Navigate to the Custom Widget Manager in SAC.

  • Upload the podiumWidget.json manifest file.

  • You do not need to upload a ZIP file, as the widget's JavaScript resources will be served from your local machine.

  • Add the widget to a story and configure it as required. Which is to select a model in the builder panel of the custom widget and choose one dimension and one measure. The podium will show the top three measure values by the selected dimension.

How the Local Server Works

The Express.js server is configured to serve static files from your project directory and includes headers to enable cross-origin resource sharing (CORS), which is required by SAC to fetch files from your local environment.

Below is the contents of server.js:

const express = require('express');
const app = express();
const port = 3000;

app.use((req, res, next) => {
  res.header('Access-Control-Allow-Origin', '*'); 
  res.header('Access-Control-Allow-Headers', 'Origin, X-Requested-With, Content-Type, Accept');
  next();
});

app.use(express.static('./'));

app.listen(port, () => {
  console.log(`Development server running at http://localhost:${port}`);
});

Key Components

  • CORS Configuration: Required for SAC to access widget files hosted on your local machine.

  • Static File Serving: Ensures that JavaScript and related files are accessible directly via browser requests.

Benefits of the Local Development Approach

  • Faster Development Cycle: Skip the need to zip and upload files for each change.

  • Immediate Feedback: Refresh the story in SAC to test the latest code instantly.

  • Better Debugging: Use browser developer tools and console logging without deployment delays.

  • Simplified Collaboration: Work locally and integrate with version control systems easily.

Considerations

  • Localhost is for development only: This setup is intended solely for local development and testing. Once your widget is fully developed and tested, you should host the resource files in a production-ready environment such as SAP Analytics Cloud itself, GitHub Pages, or any secure web server. Update the file paths in your widgetâ€™s JSON descriptor to point to the hosted URLs before deploying to production.

  • Network accessibility: Ensure that SAC can reach your local machine. You may need to use your machine's IP address if localhost is blocked or inaccessible.

  • Port conflicts: If port 3000 is already in use, update the port in both server.js and the widget manifest file.

Start your streamlined widget development journey here:
https://github.com/lkannan/analytics-cloud-creating-custom-widgets-learning-journey

Related Resources:

  • Custom Widget Detailed Blog
  • SAP Analytics Cloud Custom Widget Samples

entry.title: Google BigQuery Adapter for SAP Integration Suite
entry.content:
Many of our day-to-day business activities require storage, processing and insights - Google BigQuery is a data warehousing offering from Google that provides all of the above and much more. It can store massive volumes of data and provide quick processing and efficient analysis.

To harness the ability of Google BigQuery in your SAP Integrations, SAP has released Google BigQuery for SAP Integration Suite that facilitates management and access to data residing on Google BigQuery. Now you can maximize your productivity with data related integrations using Google BigQuery Adapter.

Google BigQuery Adapter Features

Google BigQuery Adapter has the following features:

  • Supports OAuth2 Service Account and Workload Identity Federation authentication methods.
  • Enables accessing and managing Big Query resources like datasets, jobs, tables, table data, routines, projects, row access policies, and models.
  • Supports convenient metadata retrieval using List operation data that used the Page Token field.
  • Supports Basic configuration for convenient processing capability whereas Advanced enables proficient users to perform calls with greater control while connecting to any API endpoint.
  • Supports DML operations like insert, update, patch for Google BigQuery resources.

Update a Dataset

In this blog post, we will demo a scenario to get you started with a basic Google BigQuery Adapter feature. We will see how to update details for an existing dataset residing in Google BigQuery.

The following prerequisites are required to be completed on the application side of Google BigQuery.

  • Create a dataset or have access to an existing one. For more information, see Create Datasets.
  • You must also ensure the correct permissions are available to the service user to update a dataset. For more information, see Dataset Permissions.

Create a Payload using Content Modifier

One of the first tasks we do after creating a new integration flow, is to prepare the payload that contains information to be updated in the target dataset in Google BigQuery.

 

{
  "kind": "bigquery#dataset",
  "etag": "etag_value",
  "id": "gbq_docs.org_primary_dataset",
  "selfLink": "https://bigquery.googleapis.com/bigquery/v2/projects/gbq_docs/datasets/org_primary_dataset",
  "datasetReference": {
    "projectId": "gbq_docs",
    "datasetId": "org_primary_dataset"
  },
  "friendlyName": "EmployeeDataset",
  "description": "This dataset stores analytical data.",
  "defaultTableExpirationMs": "3600000",
  "defaultPartitionExpirationMs": "86400000",
  "labels": {
    "env": "dev",
    "team": "analytics"
  }
}

 

As you can see above, we intend to add metadata details like description, tags, labels etc.

Connect to Google BigQuery using the Google BigQuery Adapter

The Connection tab contains connection and authentication parameters for Google BigQuery.

Before you set the connection details, see Creating a Keystore in the Adapter Guide.

 

ParameterDescription/Values
AddressSpecify the name for the Google BigQuery service. Default: https://bigquery.googleapis.com/
Authentication TypeSelect as OAuth2 Service Account
OAuth2 Token URL

Specify the OAuth2 Token URL which identifies as the authorization server for producing a JWT token internally.

Default: https://www.googleapis.com/oauth2/v4/token 

Client EmailSpecify the Google Service Account Client Email.
Private Key Alias

Specify the security artifact storing the Google Service Account Private Key.

Scope

Specify the scope of the connection to Google BigQuery service.

Default: https://www.googleapis.com/auth/bigquery

Update Dataset Operation

Now you can run the Update Dataset operation on your target dataset under your project.

Parameter

Description/Values

Configuration TypeSelect the required configuration type as Basic.
EntitySelect Datasets as the entity 
Project IDSpecify the Google BigQuery project ID.
Dataset IDSpecify the Dataset ID to be used.

You can achieve the same using Advanced configuration type as well.

ParameterDescription/Values
Configuration TypeSelect the required configuration type as Advanced.

HTTP Method

Select as POST.
Relative URL/bigquery/v2/projects/{projectId}/datasets/{datasetid}

Run and Verify Output

After saving the above configuration, deploy the flow and verify that the changes are reflected on the dataset. You should be able to see some of them as shown below

Labelsenv : dev team : analytics
DescriptionThis dataset stores analytical data.

Quick Links

For detailed information about Google BigQuery configuration, see Google BigQuery and Google BigQuery Adapter Guide.

Note: The Google BigQuery adapter is available as part of your SAP Integration Suite license.

entry.title: Re: Condition Contract Settlement: No Split by Company Co...
entry.content:
Hello, Thank you for your response. As suggested, I have already tested the approach of using two separate condition contracts, one for each company code (FR11 and FR09). Each contract uses a business volume selection criterion on the supplier, so that only the relevant POs are considered for each company. However, I encountered a critical issue:
-During the rebate calculation, the system correctly aggregates the total business volume.
-For example: PO1 (FR11) = â‚¬400, PO2 (FR09) = â‚¬700, PO3 (FR09) = â‚¬600 â†’ the total (â‚¬1700) correctly triggers the 10% rebate threshold.
-The problem occurs during settlement:
Contract A (FR11) creates a settlement document for the entire â‚¬1700, even though this amount consists of two line items: one for â‚¬400 (FR11) and one for â‚¬1300 (FR09). It should only consider PO1 (â‚¬400).
Contract B (FR09) also generates a settlement for the same â‚¬1700, including PO1, which does not belong to its company code. It should only apply to PO2 and PO3 (â‚¬1300).
As a result, the rebate is calculated and posted twice â€” each contract applies the rebate on the full business volume, instead of only its own POs.
Could you please confirm: Is this behavior expected in standard S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition? Is there any supported configuration or workaround that ensures each contract settles only the POs it is supposed to, even if the rebate threshold is calculated based on global volume?
Thank you in advance for your support.
Best regards,
Ghassen

entry.title: Re: Add a blank page to an Adobe Form
entry.content:
I don't know any "standard" way of doing it in a form. For sure, if you print each document in a separate spool request, there's no risk of printing second document on the back of the first one. But even if you do have several documents in one spool request, each form needs to have a flag "Duplex Flip Long Edge" marked in Adobe Designer, which forces duplex printing and "closes" a document to prevent printing on it's back (this option is not valid if you use job profiles).

If, regardless of what I've written, you still want to add a blank page, you need some scripting. For sure you need to check amount of pages:

var totalPages = xfa.layout.pageCount();

I would put a big empty subform at the end of the document, which by default is hidden. But if totalPages is an odd number, then show it - it will flow over to the next page. I'm not sure if it'll work, but I guess it's worth trying.

if( "here put a condition checking against odd numbers, maybe !totalPages.isEven() will work ){
this.presence = "visible";
}
